summary: Emacs Transient Mode Key Binding Configuration Fix

content.text: I can see the referenced code from your Emacs configuration file at `dot-emacs-dot-d/lisp/feat-ai.el:24-27`. Let me read that specific section to understand what you're showing me.

20→                 (side . right)
    21→                 (window-width . 90)))
    22→
    23→  ;; Override the transient key bindings to use Return instead of 'y' and Escape instead of 'n'

    25→    (transient-replace-suffix 'claude-code-transient "y" '("<return>" "Send <return>" claude-code-send-return))
    26→    (transient-replace-suffix 'claude-code-transient "n" '("<escape>" "Send <escape>" claude-code-send-escape)))

Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.

file.content:
(side . right)
                 (window-width . 90)))

  ;; Override the transient key bindings to use Return instead of 'y' and Escape instead of 'n'
  (with-eval-after-load 'claude-code
    (transient-replace-suffix 'claude-code-transient "y" '("<return>" "Send <return>" claude-code-send-return))
    (transient-replace-suffix 'claude-code-transient "n" '("<escape>" "Send <escape>" claude-code-send-escape)))

  (claude-code-mode))

content.text:
I see! This is a clever customization of the Claude Code transient interface in Emacs. You're overriding the default key bindings to use more intuitive keys:
- `<return>` instead of `y` for sending
- `<escape>` instead of `n` for escaping/canceling

This makes the transient interface more user-friendly by using common keys that users naturally expect for these actions.
